Steam Review: Sengoku Dynasty

Pros:

The game is incredibly fun.

The world feels expansive and immersive.

The atmosphere is captivating.

Combat is a highlight—intense and fluid, with mechanics reminiscent of Sekiro. (timing your parries, poise, etc)


Cons:

Performance Issues: The game runs poorly, even on decent hardware. With 16GB of RAM, 12GB of VRAM, and an i7-7700k, I get 12-25 FPS on average, regardless of settings, suggesting significant optimization issues.

Crashes: The crashes are severe—my monitor loses input entirely, forcing a hard restart. These crashes have also corrupted my GPU driver twice, requiring me to use DDU and reinstall drivers. I will not these crashes seem to happen almost exclusively when fast travelling or loading a save game.

System Stability: No other game I’ve played has caused such underlying issues with my PC that do not exist whilst playing other games.

Bugs: Frequent crashes have messed with game saves, leading to lost fast travel points and bugged out enemy or leader requirements in previously cleared areas.


Verdict:
The core gameplay is fantastic, but the technical issues make it hard to recommend in its current state. Proceed with caution, as these issues may vary depending on your specific hardware. That said, the developers seem engaged with the community, so there’s hope for improvements in future updates. so i do recommend it i guess in terms of it's actual gameplay but just not right now.

184898495.review: So far, Im really enjoying the game. For what it has currently, the 12 hours I've put in the game so far has been fun. As with any city survival game, it's a slow burn at first, as you familiarize yourself with the open world, the various construction blueprints, recipes, etc. And, truth be told, it felt like a bit of a grind at first, as you bring in refugees and working hard to gather and satisfy the constant need for a steady food supply, water supply, and materials stored for supplying heat in your growing village. And, it's made even a bit frustrating as tool and weapon degradation exists in this game and, because wooden tools are what's available in the beginning, be prepared for a bit extra grinding as you often have to rebuild axes and hammers as you're foraging and building. But, again, this is only for maybe the first 4 hours or so , depending on how fast your are trying to go through the many quests you are presented with. With all that aside, I've been really enjoying building my villages. Having full control and freedom of choice of the layout of my villages is exactly what I want in games like this. I find the population system pretty good, as you find and bring in refugees that wonder into your village or that you come across out in the world and assign them a home and job. It's a good amount of micromanaging that doesn't feel overwhelming or too much. It does take much of the weight off me when my villagers are able to maintain a constant supply of food and water for the village. However, one issue I have regarding the villagers is with the game's pathing. Often, I find villagers walking in circles or hitting invisible walls when I assign them to a job and they are trying to get to the building to do the job. It's a minor annoyance and easily fixable with a patch. There is a good amount of character customization, as you and your villagers craft various attire items and armor. There's a decent amount of weapons and, of course, each weapon has stronger versions you can loot or craft as you gain access to stronger materials and ores. Speaking of weapons, the combat is surprisingly pretty good. It's got a slight jank to it but it's responsive and has a decent fun factor. The various weapons do provide a bit of strategy and allows you to somewhat tailor your play-style as different weapons offer different combat styles that utilize varying reach advantages (or disadvantages), different attacks with varying combos, varying attack speeds, etc. The dodging/blocking/parrying system is quite good as well. However, the AI isn't very smart or difficult, even when facing multiple enemies, as it's quite easy to recognize when an attack is coming and the enemy has no unblockable attacks. The AI also can suffer from the same pathing issues as they will often start walking away from me, even when I'm advancing towards them, attacking them from behind and they sometimes don't react. Again, it's an easy patch fix. I have yet to experience any raids on my villages, so I don't know how the game handles AI combat, as you can make villagers soldiers to guard, patrol, and protect your village. All in all, it's a pretty good package. I really look forward to other features the devs may be planning and developing to further the fun factor.

184795996.review:
I've been playing this game nonstop for the past month but I am giving it a negative review because the optimization is too much of a problem to ignore. I'm a big fan of building games like Valheim and resource management games like Satisfactory and an even bigger fan of Japanese culture and history. Which is actually what brought my attention to this game in the first place. I recently made a Minecraft data/resource pack that reskins all of vanilla minecraft into a Japanese theme, I even called it Sengoku Jidai too. 

I really like the building and the resource management, it reminded me of Age of Empires except I can actually sit back and treat it like the Sims instead of devoting 100% of my attention and stress. They are a lot of QoL changes this game could use such as a better graph that tells you how many resources you are producing and consuming that is a lot more clear and cohesive than the first one. There's also a weird bug where the tool a village uses for their job will get replaced with a random item like a stick which will clog production. 

The combat is serviceable and not too bad if you try not to compare it too much to Sekiro or Ghost of Tsushima. Enemy AI can be bugged sometimes and abused. 

Anyway, the big thing i'm talking about here is the optimization as I said before. It's a huge problem and needs to be fixed. My computer is on the higher end and can run pretty much any game, I even got perfect frames at the beginning of this game but as you progress and get more villagers you're frames will tank immensely. I'm talking 20 fps in the later game. I understand this is a building game and the more things you place the more performance-demanding it is, but I restarted the whole game and kept the assets I was placing to a bare minimum and it still reached levels of unbearable. 

Keep in mind I have hundreds of hours in Satisfactory; a 3D base building and automation game also coded in Unreal and I've hardly had any performance issues despite the thousands of assets I've placed down that are making multiple calculations in the background. Sengoku Dynasty is an automation game in a way but nowhere near to this complexity and yet manages to destroy my frames. Therefore I can't see this problem being something impossible for the devs to tackle and they need to patch it as soon as possible.  

The reason why I'm passionate about this problem is because I really do like this game. This game is right up my alley due to my tastes but for anyone else I wouldn't recommend it due to its sheer performance problems. If this ever gets fixed I will be more than happy to return it and give it a good review.

Sengoku Dynasty turned out to be a very enjoyable experience for me. First and foremost, I was impressed by the beautifully designed world – the graphics are truly pleasing to the eye, and the environment invites you to explore and discover its secrets. The building system is one of the best I’ve ever seen. It’s intuitive, satisfying, and offers a lot of creative freedom, making it a real joy to develop my settlement.

I also loved how versatile the game is – from resource management to village development, there’s so much to do. The mechanics are engaging, although not all of them feel fully polished. Some of them gave me the impression they were originally intended for something else, which affects their overall cohesion a bit.

The story is simple, but that works in its favor – it doesn’t overwhelm you and lets you focus on enjoying the gameplay itself. The resource management system works well enough, although I think it could be a little more intuitive.

On the downside, there are a few things that bothered me. For instance, the lack of livestock is understandable from a historical perspective, but the absence of horses and the ability to ride them was quite disappointing. The world sometimes feels a bit empty – there are no NPCs walking along the paths, and random events involving characters could have added more life to the experience. The enemy AI also falls short of expectations.

Despite these flaws, Sengoku Dynasty offers plenty of satisfaction and enjoyment. I’ve spent many delightful hours with this game, and I can genuinely recommend it, even though it’s not perfect.

I am writing the negative review for this game with a heavy heart, because I absolutely loved playing the early access version. The village building is fun, managing your villages's needs can be difficult but generally manageable, and the visuals and sound are beautiful and immersive. The basic gameplay loop feels pretty good and seeing your village grow from nothing to a bustling town is satisfying.
That being said, this game should not be released yet. It was fantastic for an early access game. There were many issues, but I though to myself, these will surely be fixed with the full release. 
I was wrong.
The game as it is now simply feels unfinished. I have to wonder if the developers even bothered to have dedicated playtests done. The issues I'm seeing here aren't even major things, since the essential gameplay works, but small quality of life issues that cause the game to die of a thousand paper cuts. For example, your hunger bar is in the bottom left corner, where you rarely look if you are just building your town, but there is no audio queue to tell you that you are hungry, so I have starved to half my health before even realizing that I need to eat. You can set the exact amount of an item your villagers should craft or gather, in some cases on a range of 1-250, but you have to do it via clicking on the increase/decrease arrow repeatedly. You can upgrade previously built beds, but that registers them as new bed and the previous bed as destroyed, so your assigned villager not only loses their home, but their job, and you have to reassign everything for them again (and click on decrease 100 times again). There is no way to filter the UI for a certain job, so if you want to know how many villagers are gathering wood for example, you have to scroll and look and hope that you aren't missing any woodworkers you have assigned.
I am honestly severely disappointed. This game is feature complete, but feels like not a second was spent on making sure that the existing features don't just work, but work well. My original concern with Sengoku Dynasty would be that it was a copy-paste of Medieval Dynasty, just reskinned.  I'm happy to say that's not the case, and they've added some solid innovation to the "Dynasty" formula.

A couple of highlights for players who are familiar with Medieval Dynasty:
[list][*] No weight!  Instead you have limited inventory slots as the limiting factor, but no more struggling to move because you picked up too many logs.
[*] The "conquest" of regions unlocks new resources and technologies.  And "conquest" doesn't necessarily mean fighting the bandits; it can be as simple as constructing a watchtower in a region or rebuilding a bridge along a border.
[*] There are several "project" sites, which require a number of resources to be delivered and workers assigned.  However, once complete these add unique structures to the world (and usually give you a bonus).
[*] Skills unlock much more quickly, which leads to a steady feeling of progress.  I'm not 100% sure on this, but there doesn't seem to be a level/skill cap for each of the paths - so given enough time, you may be able to unlock all the skills.

If you enjoy Medieval Dynasty and want to try something similar (but still unique), or if you're just interested in a "peasant-focused" resource management and city-builder game, I highly recommend giving Sengoku Dynasty a try.

tl;dr It's good, but it doesn't hold your hand.

There's a lot to appreciate about this game. There's lots of reasons to explore (finding shrines, foraging, etc), the project and liberation systems are satisfying, it's visually great and the combat is pretty solid. The entire system of recruitment & housing & expansion & villager needs is pretty transparent and engaging, and the way advancement is tied to the metaplot is pretty neat.

All that being said, it expects you to explore and experiment. For example, straw. You'll need a lot of straw over time. It's made from grass, and you can hand-craft it at a 2:1 ratio. However, if you look around in the construction interface (i.e. hold a hammer, right click and explore the radial menu), you can find a Drying Rack. Not only does it fully automate the crafting (grass converts to straw over time, place grass and collect straw later), it produces it at a 1:1 ratio. [i]Absolutely nothing even hinted this existed.[/i]

It badly needs an internal wiki or reference, where you can look items up, see what they do and how/where they're produced. Right now there's a pile of things you can unlock with (non-microtransaction) currency, but it's hard to tell what's useful from that interface.

All that being said, a rough gem is still a gem. It really wants for some QoL, but what exists today is a solid experience.

I didn't read any guides when I started out, reading guides usually ruins the game for me, I like to figure things out on my own. So, managing the village upkeep doesn't leave you much room to screw up and it's never really fully automated, you always need to craft or gather something. You'll be pulling your hair out trying to manage the village with its awful lists and misinformed abstract production numbers and no way to easily calculate the total expenditure of your resources. First of all, every building needs to be linked up to the correct storage facilities. At first, the general storage will do, but eventually you need to build several other types of storage buildings, each requiring a building of their own and you need to make sure that each production building is properly set up. I had a ton of trouble managing the village maintenance, because four carpenters in a village of less than thirty people were barely able to keep up with the maintenance quota, my rickety shacks were suddenly falling apart left and right, the only way I managed produce any lumber again was to get a large stockpile of clay, mine it manually and then burn through it in hopes of getting more villagers. But if you think that getting more villagers might help - you're dead wrong! The more people your "dynasty" has, the more stuff they need. Why do I need to manually change each forager individually to pick different a different type of mushroom during the summer and winter? - Why can't you just tell them to go pick up any edible mushroom they come across that happens to be available in each season - there are many such similar annoying cases of micromanagement with this game. You cannot set up a proper production of items separately for each season, you need to always fiddle and tinker around with the people's workplace or micromanage the menus and it gets really bothersome to do with the janky lists and the scarce amount of information. So, after cough medicine, comes security, which means more work for the blacksmith to craft weapons, in addition to the hammers, axes, adzes, knives, bells and whistles that they're already crafting! That also means you need to designate some of your villagers as 'warriors' at guard towers to guard them from enemies that never seem to invade your village. I can see the vision, but this game needs A LOT of work. The concept of building a bustling town by hand is very appealing, but this game just feels dead. None of the NPCs really matter. All your villagers just exist to produce and consume resources. They do not feel like your faithful townspeople, they are robots. There is no one to latch onto. They say nothing of substance. Not to mention that they are butt ugly and visually identical to each other. In playing from the actual perspective of the town's leader, I would imagine there's at least a surface-level connection to my people, but I feel nothing for them. They barely even benefit me. Everything they do is in service of meeting the consumption/production quota. Why wouldn't I just play a traditional city builder? What's the point of me having boots on the ground?

That's my main criticism, but there are other things that irk me, too. 

There's little point in having a season system. All the food sources you're likely using still function year round. There's no temperature system or anything so winter is just a visual change. You don't need to wear warm clothes, nor do your townspeople. Same idea with summer.

There's a clothing slot for gloves but in 14 hours I have seen no glove items. They might not exist. I've read that the slot is a holdover from early access that wasn't removed in 1.0 [EDIT: this has apparently been fixed in a post 1.0 update]. That's already pretty annoying to me, but wait until you hear about the "Dynasty" part of "Sengoku Dynasty".

Here is a quote from the store page:
"DYNASTY MANAGEMENT: Create a prosperous dynasty for generations to come. Oversee the growth and development of your villages. Get married and ensure your legacy continues through your successor."

As you can see, one of the main selling points of this game is starting a family of your own, thereby "ensuring your legacy continues". But when you approach someone who you aim to start a family with, you're explicitly told in a pop-up message that your kid won't actually get to grow up and do adult things until an update that comes later. They'll be eternally stuck as children in the meantime. This game is seriously called Sengoku Dynasty when there is no such dynasty to be found in 1.0. Here's the Merriam-Webster definition of "dynasty": 

1
: a succession of rulers of the same line of descent 
a dynasty that ruled China for nearly 300 years
2
: a powerful group or family that maintains its position for a considerable time
born into a powerful political dynasty
a baseball dynasty

SENGOKU DYNASTY? MORE LIKE... SENGOKU... THE-DYNASTY-ENDS-WITH-ME! The first definition definitely does not fit here, since you will be the ONLY ruler with no such role being passed to your children because they will be babies forever. Ironically, the second definition actually does fit because you will be ruling for an ETERNITY! You could sleep tens of years away in this game and the only thing different would be the ever increasing size of your stockpile. Seasons will change, years will pass, but no one will age, no NPC towns will grow, and resources will stay plentiful. It's like the whole world is inside a time bubble. Your town will steadily grow each year... and the first villager you recruited in year 1 will still be alive to witness you welcoming villager 274 in year 102. Your kid will still be a baby, too. This really adds to my whole robot comparison.

Did I mention that villagers can't have their own babies? If you want new villagers, you have to manually scour the world for people that magically appear every season. They're all robots, I tell you.

Besides the "Dynasty" part being incomplete, another missing feature slated for LATER is enemy raids. Despite this, my people will still desire "security", aka another number for the robots to consume. Why should I, as a player, care about the security of my automatons when I KNOW there is no real threat? That feature is coming later guys, you don't need protection!

Combat is also disappointing. Enemies can only see a few meters, but hey, at least they have 360 degree vision. Enemies don't aggro as a group either, just inch into an enemy's vision circle (not cone) so you can pick them off one by one. Spears also make this game super easy; just take one step back, press attack, and the enemy will walk right into the hitbox because enemies can only walk straight at you (which also gets them stuck on obstacles). To compare this combat to something like Dark Souls would be an insult to actual good games (I'm looking at you, other reviewers). 

What I've written about is just annoyances that I could come up with off the top of my head. There is more I could write about if I opened the game again and dug a bit deeper, but I'd rather not see this game again for another year or two or three. The most fun I had with this game was thinking about my android peasants being stuck in time for an eternity, aka writing this review. 

Basically, this game has no personality and shouldn't be in 1.0. It's objectively unfinished and they can't even bother to act like it's done. It's amateurish slop.

Best way I can describe it: it's like a mini ghost of Tsushima (open medieval japanese world with exploration, settlements, bandit camps to conquer, and NPCs with their own stories, albeit on a smaller sacle), with deep village building (as expected from a Toplitz published game). 

Pros:
- The Peasant Kingdom premise is fun and interesting
- The Devs seem genuinely invested in improving the game and responding to the community
- The combat is surprisingly fun and satisfying, was not expecting that. It does not feel like an after thought.
- The amount of Japanese cultural decor and aesthetics you can build in your village is really nice, and surely to please at least a western weeb audience (can't speak for what an actual Japanese would think, though based on comment sections I've translated, they seem positive. - Tons of flexibility in settings, allowing the player a fine degree of control over all the systems, speed of building, FOV, difficulty, etc.


Cons:
- Generally moderate to severe level of jank throughout, but nothing too immersion breaking. They got the important stuff right.
- In rare occasions, performance is a bit weird. I'm playing on a 4070ti, and every now and then I'll get weird screen stutters and frame jumps. Large villages can get laggy.
- The inventory screen is a bit much, especially just starting out. after 8 hours i still am getting lost a bit with all the options and work stations
- The village job management mechanics are satisfying when they work, but not always very intuitive


Overall devs did a great job, and if you are a gamer who is patient with some cumbersome systems and jank, enjoy the medieval Japanese setting and the survival crafting genre, I'm confident you will enjoy this.

I'm looking forward to progressing through the story and working on my village building skills, and exploring the relationship and other mechanics. I can already tell that even if there isn't much more than this, there is enough in the village building to get my money's worth.

Decent game with alright amount of content. 
The major drawback for me is the repetitive nature of recruiting new members for your villages. You literally need to pray for RNG to spawn refugees near you. If you aren't lucky, the only alternative is running around the map for 20+ minutes to be able to find some or sleeping to progress to the next season for zone refreshes.
The resource management is a pain in the butt and the UI was completely bastardized to allow for console gameplay. It's very obvious that they changed the UI to let this game be played on console, without regard to how much this impairs a PC players ability to look at what your village is generating and consuming. The needs are balanced decently, but the bad resource management makes it difficult to understand what you need to build next or change production to.
The production system is basically a matter of selecting different recipes for your assigned worker to craft for you, which is great in theory but fails to be good in reality. The process of choosing a recipe is a mess because you can't see what your village is actively producing and consuming on other crafting jobs. 
The processing is done all in a single batch at the end of the day, so you don't get incremental resource dropped into storage throughout the day. This means you'll end up having production of 100+ logs but no logs to build with for the day because the workers haven't deposited yet. This is another hurdle for managing the economy because there's a lot of guesswork needed to plan what resources you need vs what you already have.
There are massive performance issues related to changing seasons and work processing at the end of the day. There are framerate issues within a city with a lot of player buildigns and npcs. This game does not scale up very well, but that may be my own hardware limitation. I don't have a top of the line PC but that's no excuse for framerate drops and freezing with all low settings.

Overall, I give this game a headache / 10.

This is a review of my experience with SD. I can be picky, and the more frustrated I get over something usually means I really like it and selfishly want it to reach full potential. So if you disagree with my opinion, just slap a jester and move on.

I have gone back and forth during EA to play updates, and now with 1.0, I gotta say meh... It's so hard to say that because it's close to what I'm looking for but has a shallow feeling at times. I do like this game, and I paid $30 for it, so I'm not mad at the value. I'm disappointed because I think they could do a lot more with it, but the developer seems to be focused on adding more content and mechanics, whereas I believe village mechanics, the core gameplay, needs improving.

First off, for you RP gamers, this game is not ideal for inner RP. The game systems will constantly snap you out of immersion. You need to try hard not to find the village lifeless if you are not looking to have 15-20+ people in a village. I had a village of 12, not a lot, I know, but I was really going for a small village. I had villagers who dance on the roof, walk way out into the wilderness, get stuck in a loop because of a boulder in their path, or chilling in a house they have no business being in. Its just a mess from an RP point; from a gamer standpoint, I can fast travel/sleep to fix a lot of villager issues and move on with my life, but I ask you all, in a game about villager management/building, should that not be the mechanic that gets perfected?

-QoL!!!!
How in the heck are they talking about developing a new map when systems could be reworked? The UI is rough and bare. I'm sorry, but it is. For a game that's supposed to be about management (I think?) they offer very little information or control over it. I get frustrated every time I do something simple like assign a villager to a house because you have no way of identifying the house, which forces you to go one at a time or play musical beds to get people where you want. Something so trivial and simple not being put in makes me believe they WANT you thinking of the villagers as nothing more than a resource to be filled, nothing deeper than simply adding them to the village that's short on labor. On the topic of labor and jobs, holy cow, there are SO MANY positions to be filled! You need someone just to pick up water from the well, move it to a box next to it, and that's it! That is their whole existence. I need to feed heat and sleep this dude just so I got someone to grab water. Yes, I can grab the water myself, but considering I have to do everything else in this management game, Id like the ability to have villagers that can mentally handle doing something like getting water from the well when a recipe needs it. I did not encounter odd bugs, only one CTD, and it was during an alt-tab'n so no complaints. 

-Gameplay
Really fun the first village playthrough, but I can't see myself replaying full playthroughs with It's limited depth unless mod support happens. 1.0 motivated me to play, and I love the combat. Im a builder, so going in, I DGAF about combat, nor did I have faith that this lovely Janky game would execute it well, but I was wrong! Combat is smooth-ish (still playing GoT, so im trying not to judge on a curve). The stikes and sounds are great, and the animations are smooth unless you spaz with the mouse. The AI is still walking up sides of cliffs or doing small circles in the woods, but I'm not sure if that's a bug. This has happened since I got the game, so if it's not fixed yet, then it's a feature, not a bug. 
-Village Locations
(Disclaimer: I am very picky with base/house placement in games TBF, and "good" is highly subjective.)
In my mind's eye, I had this idea of a small mountain village next to a stream with multiple levels and tons of trees. I learned quickly that wasn't happening. There are so many places in this game that I thought were beautiful and wanted to build, but sadly and not surprisingly, they were locations that were taken by the new bandit camps or existing towns. They built wonderful unique environments around towns as well as the bandit areas and, in my opinion, went vanilla in player build areas. The theme seemed to just be large, flat space. Its still beautiful, and I'm trying not to type negative here but really look around the towns and bandit areas, then visit the areas that can actually host a larger village, and you will notice it missing what I don't have the right words to describe. The game seems to want you to build big towns in order to progress, like its bigger and bigger and not better and more efficient. The whole gameplay loop is chop wood, build a big ass shack with 5 different redundant storages and a table that does the actual function of the building, chop wood, unlock a recipe needing 1 mat from an entirely second building with 5 redundant storages, chop wood, and do quests asking you to craft something that requires 3 buildings with 5 redundant storages each.
The Village Buildings
Building exteriors look cool and very RP-friendly, but the build grid is difficult if you want to make them match up to create walkways. So if you are trying to build a village like the premade ones, then good luck and bless your patience. Interiors are drab, but it was the time after all, so I'm good with the look. I just absolutely loathe the multiple redundant storages that the AI doesn't even interact with. 

I DO like this game, and I did get my money's worth, and I will continue playing my coastal RP village from time to time in the hopes that further refinement goes into the game. I'll admit some of my issues with the game are created from what the game is not, which might not be the fairest way to review something. The Road map however, paints a picture of they are happy with the state of the game and are now ready to add more, so if thats the case, it's a bummer.

Sengoku Dynasty - Promising, But Not Ready Yet

I’ve put in about 25 hours into Sengoku Dynasty, and while the game starts off with some promise, I can’t recommend it in its current state. It’s technically out of Early Access, but honestly, it feels like it’s still in development — especially when it comes to multiplayer.

Multiplayer is Rough:
The multiplayer experience is extremely laggy, and that’s being generous. I’m running a high-end PC (RTX 4090, Ryzen 3900X, 128GB RAM), and the performance is still awful. The game constantly struggles to keep up, and enemies often just wander around aimlessly without attacking. You can hit them like they’re ragdolls, and it feels more like you’re testing a broken demo than playing an actual game.

FPS Issues:
Once you start raiding the Ronin camps, the FPS drops to unplayable levels (2-8 FPS). It’s hard to focus on combat when the game is struggling to even render the action. Enemies are nearly impossible to hit, and the lag makes it all frustrating rather than fun.

City Building is the Highlight:
The city-building mechanics are decent and the most polished part of the game. You can create and manage a village, and it’s enjoyable as long as you can look past the other issues. But unfortunately, that’s where the positives end.

Final Thoughts:
Sengoku Dynasty has a lot of potential, but it feels unfinished and unpolished right now. If you’re hoping for a stable multiplayer experience or smooth gameplay, you’ll be disappointed. SINGLE PLAYER IS FINE THOUGH! The city-building is solid, but the game needs a lot of work to make it enjoyable overall. I’d recommend waiting at least 2-3 years for updates, assuming the devs continue to improve it. Hopefully by then, it’ll be worth playing.

[h1] A Positive But Scathing Review: Decent With BIG Caveats [/h1]

This game has potential. I actually enjoy playing and wish the studio the best. However, a lot of things are ill-optimized or buggy. For example, dropped rotten food doesn't despawn after (sometimes) restarting and hours in game, a common computationally saving measure in many games. While trivial as a benefit for freeing memory, I understand not implementing it because of complexity of making a garbage collector--but I suspect a rush to core features is present in other parts of the game as well. The game right now is okay, and coming from M&B as a modder and almost lifelong player, I seriously hope these guys succeed with this title so that it doesn't stay this mediocre. 

The roadmap addresses some shortcomings of the game as it is. However I'd compare this game to Bannerlord while it was still in Early Access. As a 1.0 release this is kind of lacking. 

[h2] What it Does Well: [/h2]
This title brings some pretty cool things to the table, but nothing industry-pioneering. This is essentially a thematically consistent version of Conan Exiles with more extensive village management and more cookie-cutter buildings. It brings the quintessential single player experience--something always-online games lack. I like this over Conan Exiles for exactly this reason. The cookie cutter buildings reduces complexity while also bringing a nice custom experience to gameplay. 

Combat is somewhat satisfying. It mixes a lot of good things from different games, but is fundamentally almost Dark Souls like. There is also custom difficulty settings, which is always welcome. This game also has a nice perk system. This games brings a bunch of awesome features from other games into one.

[h2] Critiques: Oh Boy... [/h2]
Things aren't fully implemented. There is a "Daimyo" system, and they have only recently implemented 14-15th century Samurai armor as well as respective weapons, which is comical that anyone played this before this update as this would've been more accurately "Peasant Kingdom" than "Sengoku Dynasty" prior to this release. Furthermore, [b] there is no currently implemented follower mechanics [/b]. You are literally just roaming around everywhere by yourself, with no army or force to speak of, cheesing camps of sometimes 20 combatants. You are nowhere close to being a "Daimyo" let alone some sort of "Sengoku" character.

Quests and the world is kind of... meh. Interfacing with NPCs is essentially reading walls of text. You aren't particularly compelled to be immersed in the open world. In comparison to something like Kingdom Come: Deliverance this is almost amateurish in world building. This feels lackluster in comparison, but I still recommend this game because it is so difficult to design and implement and hope they improve.

The way they implemented security as well is...meh. You can give them weapons, but they essentially don't do much and stand around looking busy. They also keep their refugee clothes while using high-end weapons, while having high-end armor just sitting in storage. You don't feel like a "Daimyo" with a samurai army in "Sengoku" Japan as much as you are a heavily armored babysitter.

[b] Performance is also incredibly surprising in a bad way. This game chugs along and drops frames for a pretty minimal benefit-to-cost. [/b]

This game also has so much marketing material that I'd wish they spent those man-hours on game development. 

Their promotional video talks about "supporting Sengoku Dynasty long after release". Arguably this is not a finished game. Other studios like Taleworld have somewhat dropped the ball by releasing a barebones game--a mistake that has costed them their reputation, and one I hope this studio does not replicate.

[h2] Wishlist: [/h2]
[list]
   [*] A follower system to properly play as a "Daimyo"
   [*] Performance optimization
   [*] A more dynamic map/combat 
   [*] More strategy elements for combat and map dynamics
   [*] Extended cosmetics--Sengoku era samurai often had clan-specific crests (kamon). 
   [*] Steam Deck support
   [*] More free-flowing decision making (i.e. being able to fight friendly NPCs or play as a bandit)
[/list]

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
Honestly an okay title if it improves. A lot of great things and core features available. An offline-available single player experience. However, it [b] REALLY [/b] needs to be improved on.

If you're coming from MD and hoping for a MD experience in Japan, this is going to be hit and miss. Sengoku offers numerous unique systems (such as liberating regions, combat*, and the obvious Japanese aesthetic) and enough familiar ones that those who have played similar games can more or less dive right in. 

Unfortunately, a lot of those more unique systems feel very anemic to the point of being annoying. Combat for example recently underwent an extensive overhaul but the result was something I low key wish wasn't even there (and this is someone who loves combat in these games). It's overly simplistic, easy to cheese even when you're not trying to, and the AI is... well, not great. Unfortunately in order to progress in this game you MUST engage with it, so there's no real ignoring it. 

Whereas MD has many interlocking systems that are dependent on one another, Sengoku's feels both convoluted and flat. For example, there are many, MANY kinds of storage types, from food to wood to general and more; the thing is, you don't actually need anything other than the general storage, and your people will pull from that storage for all their needs which makes everything else at best redundant and at worst useless despite the other storage types being locked behind technology and such.

Villagers are also incredibly simplistic. There are no more stats or preferences, anyone can do anything at any time and be juts as efficient as anyone else. This might not matter to some but it really snaps you out of the immersive feeling of being in a living settlement. To add to that, there are very, VERY few actual animations the villagers will do throughout the day which just lends to that 'dead' feeling. For some reason the devs seem to have acknowledge that early on and added special 'furniture' you can buy that the villagers will 'work' at to display a little more life, which seems like an odd workaround but I digress.

It's not a bad game, and it's getting a thumbs up from me, but compared to MD (which is both unfair and understandable) it just seems a bit flat. It's a solid foundation though, and it's worth getting in my opinion.

If that is the case, the devs have indeed created an RPG. And it is actually quite good at this. But without quests and personalities, you are stuck with gated adventuring and combat situations that lead towards new areas.

Combat though, just sucks. Absolutely sucks. I'm not overstating that it is without doubt the most bug ridden useless piece of junk ever released. In theory, the one to one combat has nuance and flair. But the ranged attacks are god awful, the enemy pathing is abysmal, and I'm running out of bad words to use. Truly terrible. Never should have been released, and I would be ashamed as a dev to say that it is in a 'release 1.0 state' at all.

So where does it go from here? I could imagine new expansion lands, new items to build, new crops to grow (and god help us because seasons for your crops is an exercise in self-abuse for the player). This would all be pointless because it wouldn't address the real challenges.

Can they fix combat? Sure. Everybody else has. Lets assume they can too.
Can they make the village management better? The screen redesign would be in theory very simple and helpful and add some overall statistics. 
But. 
Yes, that's a standalone statement. I'm just feeling that the devs are in love with their own interface and had it developed by separate sub-teams who just didn't talk or share with each other. So I'm betting the answer here is actually a hard 'no'.
Can they introduce personalities and quests? What would be the point in this and how would it work with the other things so sadly lacking. Not clear how this would make it better, or fit thematically.

And now for the good bit(s). The game is absolutely beautiful. The visuals are at least an eight out of ten. Building your buildings is fun for a while and rewarding in a repeated-clicking manner. But after a time, its just make-work. If you have a whole bunch of cool stuff available, make it have an impact. Make your village impossible to build without paying attention to detail. But then illuminate those details to the player. That would be extremely cool, and in keeping with the style. To make this a great village simulator, with complex systems, they need to be intelligible without a spreadsheet. Help us envision that. Force us to make beautiful and functional homes, and to husband those scarce resources to best effect. Give me easy ways to create repeat buildings, and let me focus on the new stuff and making everything individualised (with game impact driven by it).

And for god sake, take away the stamina bar. Sure, in combat would be fine. But everywhere else, just ditch it. Hosing your own game is never smart.

Would I buy it again? On special, yes, absolutely. But it is a one-and-done game. And there was a lot of swearing, and an awfully large amount of 'why the hell did they do it that way' discussion. Not in a positive light, to be clear. The pretty graphics made it liveable, but I would not recommend it with the flaws. They are too deep, and too obvious. If they were going to be fixed, they would already be fixed. So this one is on a pathway downwards unless there is a change at the helm.

Eventually, as you discover more of the area, you will come across other resources, but some of them are in constant demand, so you need to do resource runs. And there is always something missing. Not only quantity wise (your axe will soon be your best friend), but also quality wise. And then it is a matter of the hen and the egg. At one point, I was asked to produce steel tools. Naturally, the NPCs would not allow me to use their forge, so I had to go home and build one. But to build one, you need to be a certain “dynasty” level, which is mostly done by recruiting (otherwise mostly useless) villagers. And then you need other resources, and tools, which require new resources and buildings to make… the list is endless. Which would not be problematic, if there was some sort of natural progression. 
Combat felt like a transplant, something pushed into the game to make it less dull. After having bum-rushed by wolves for the third time, the charm wore off quickly though. For some reason, boars, wolves and especially bears are much harder than the NPC bandits. And unlike bandits, they don’t have a visible health bar, for some reason. I can understand the immersion factor in not knowing their health, but on the other hand, humans have a health bar, and so do your tools.
There is some sort of quest system in place, but it is very basic and honestly not much fun. It also decidedly needs more information on how to accomplish certain goals. 
Talking about basic: there is no voice over at all after the intro. Granted the conversations with the NPCs aren’t especially exciting anyway. 
For how basic the game is, it is surprisingly hardware-demanding. I had to tune down some of the recommended settings because my computer started to make worrying levels of noise. There really is no reason why such a quaint game should be more resource demanding than say Cyberpunk 2077. Clearly, optimization is possible (and badly needed).

Verdict: Would not buy again.
Recommendation: Wait a year and then buy for 20 $ or less.

168281600.review:
Do I recommend this game?

The short answer is "Yesn't".

------------------------------------

Pros:

I personally enjoy the game-play loop of gathering resources > building > recruiting villagers > gather resources > and so on.  This is a great game to shut your brain off and build a scenic Japanese village over time.  But at the same time, i recognize that this is not a lot of player's cup of tea.

The game runs pretty well on my 3070ti and only suffers performance hits when entering some of the larger villages (around 5-10 fps drop).

While content is still pretty lean, the game seems to be updated fairly regularly and many of my complaints in the next section may soon be addressed.

------------------------------------

Moving to the cons of this game:

Combat is both too simple and too difficult, it's hard to tell where an enemy's attacks will land, there's no blocking or parry feature as far as I can tell which forces you to either try to manually sprint away before being hit or you have to just tank the damage. It's hard to predict animal's hit boxes and all the raider's I've fought use spears which are pretty much impossible to fight with a katana. There is also a lack of audio queues or other feedback that could help make combat more enjoyable.  But as i understand it, this is likely to be addressed in a future update.

Lack of customization and NPC depth is a big complaint for me.  Having played games like Rimworld where you can control almost every aspect of your colonists, including the clothes and weapons they use to compliment their specific jobs and skill sets, I find this game severely lacks in those departments.  I'd love to see my villagers have specific traits that make them better at one job over another, or more adept at certain combat styles.  I'd also like to be able to give my villagers specialized clothes to align with their jobs (IE Give my guards armor).  I feel these villagers can be better fleshed out in so many ways, including relationships, family bonds, etc.  After awhile, they just kinda feel like mute slaves instead of your friends and neighbors.

Lastly, I find the building in this game a bit disappointing.  I expected it to be more akin to Valheim or ARK where I can create whatever structures I want with snapable parts (i'll admit that's on me tho). Aside from fences, farming plots, and some other structures this isn't the case.  All core buildings are prefabs with certain furniture and entrance requirements.  While you can further change the layout of entrances, building materials, and some furniture it leads me to feeling a bit restricted in making my village feel like a unique town.  But I also understand that this may be intentional as it both forces the villages to look more authentic and is directly tied to how resource production works in this game, so I doubt that part will change.

------------------------------------

TLDR:

If you like chill resource gathering games like Valheim, some mild colony management, or are super interested in this period of Japanese history it's a game I think you should wishlist or purchase when it goes on sale.

As it stands currently, there's bones for a great game here but much of it needs to be fleshed out.  Until that happens, or they add workshop/mod support to bridge the content gap, I have a hard time recommending this game to anyone but the most hardcore base builder/colony sim enthusiast.

While I really wanted to like this game despite several technical flaws, weird animations, and simply underwhelming (to the point of a nonexistent) combat system, I couldn't recommend it even one year after several major updates after the release. 

Technically, the game is still in EA, so something might change upon release, but in its current state, I cannot recommend it. 

The game offers little to no progression, the gameplay loop becomes a list of chores that take a lot of time, and the crafting/village management system is abysmal. 

For example, there are two variations of a log: a premium and a regular one. Premium ones produce premium planks and regular ones. Pretty simple, right? 

If you started building with regular ones and ran out of them, you can run to your Dynasty Wood Storage, pick some premium logs, take them to the carpentry stations, and craft premium planks. The thing is that you can only use them if you use a special tool - adze - to debark a log and then pick up that log. Not even the plank itself - a log!

And the thing is that only the iron adze can be used to debark the premium logs. And those cannot be crafted (at least at my station), so I need to teleport to another village, look for a trader with an iron adze, get back to my village, do the thing with the log just because the game doesn't allow me to use the materials that I already have because I crafted them at the carpentry station and "didn't debark the stupid log." 

Some might say that's nothing. But the problem is that the whole game is like that. For every good mechanic, there's some convoluted bullshit that doesn't add anything to the game, and it's there. 

My biggest laugh was when I finally decided to plant some rice and do some farming in general. 

For rice, you need a field with water, which you can create as easily as regular water. The other plants need watering, right? So, for this, you need to build a well and get a bucket. My idea was that I would just build a well and then craft a bucket, get some water from the well, water my plants, and refill the bucket. Rinse and repeat until your plants are watered. 

Lol no.

You craft multiple buckets, then THROW them into the well, then WAIT, and then come back and pick up the water. Without the buckets, they are gone. You then craft another bucket at the woodworking table and combine the water from your inventory with this newly created bucket to craft a water bucket. 

That's just some hilarious game design. 

While you can hire villagers to perform most of the tasks for you, in the beginning, you won't have that luxury and will spend a lot of time running around back and forth to your storage and repeating the same tedious stuff again and again. The sense of progression in this game is really slow. 

Even 8 hours into the game, I was still running around picking up some grass because I needed a lot of it, and the game doesn't provide you with an abundance of it like other similar games do. Technically, you can make all of your foragers run around and gather some grass for you, but then they won't be collecting other, more important things like shrooms or WASABI. 

The Needs of the villagers and production tab doesn't make any sense. What do tabs "Items storage" and "Needs in storage" mean? Do my villagers require 575 firewood every day? Or one firewood is "5" Needs for heating, which you can only see after you click on the item. While I kinda figured out how it's calculated, I still don't know how to produce enough food for all my villagers, and I have 2 giant farm plots, 3 fishermen, 2 foragers, and one hunter. More than half of the population is working to provide food, and still more is needed. 

And while you could assign more people where needed, except for farming, all other jobs require new buildings and stations, which is, again, resources and time to build them. 

So, in the end, you are just running around, trying to hunt some boars (don't make me even get to the shooting mechanics in this game) to feed your population just so they can eat everything you bought to them in one sitting so tomorrow you can repeat the process again. 

Whatever out of 10.

This is a world building, farming, hunting and fishing simulator set in Japan's Sengoku period, which is a period of warring states prior to the merging of power under a Shogun.  You start as a shipwrecked refugee and must band together with other refugees to build a new home for yourself.  Actually you get to design and build several villages.  There is a generously sized map to explore and several villages and other habitations to find and interact with.  I've played for about 60 hours, and think I have seen most of the early access content.  At the moment there is one simple plot arc per village, and a number of structures (mostly bridges) to build around the map. 

Starting out was fairly easy, but the complexity of resource management gets significantly harder as you add more people to your village.  This is good as it increases the challenge, but also bad as it is difficult to completely automate your village (or I'm not getting it right).  There are options to control how much of each resource is produced which helps, but I find it necessary to manually reassign my workers for each season, especially winter.  The recently added "Needs" tab in the menus certainly helps, but the UI gets a bit flaky  when a lot of jobs have been created in the village, particularly if you use a controller.  

Going forward, I would like to see a set of story arcs driving you forward to greater heights, with the gradual ability to fully automate the early resource management features, so that the player can concentrate on the new challenges that the later game will impose.

I admittedly have only about 10 hours of game time in Sengoku Dynasty, but based on a game that is still under development, I can make a positive recommendation to other players. 

To be sure, there is a learning curve in some areas of the game, and trial-and-error in functions such as recruiting villagers and making sure they are fed and happy, can be frustrating at first. However, this game is not unlike many other sandbox oriented games, where trial-and-error and a lack of clear, step-by-step procedures make the word "it's an adventure in itself" a true statement. In other words, if you want your hand held, don't buy. If you don't mind slapping your forehead in that "ah ha!" moment, wanting then to restart a new game having suddenly mastered how you should build your village and plan for that first villager to settle, then this game definitely hits the target.  

The game itself is beautiful, and finishing an early quest of planting your bell tower in the ground before building an equally beautiful village, is a pretty cool thing.  The current pallet of wild animals keeps you on your toes, and will take your life if not careful.  Food and other resource management, as well as the progression of building structures available based on certain resource combinations,  are initially unclear, but become clearer when making mistakes turns to mastery-by-experimentation. I suspect these minor shrouds on game play dynamics will be lifted by the designers at some point.

The game has tremendous promise and as such I recommend it.  In some ways, the trial-and-error aspect of this game in my first 10 hours of playing it has felt familiar to how I learned how to play Valheim.  At some point in Valheim, I hit the "now I understand moment" on so many formerly frustrating issues. Like Valheim, and in some ways more so, Sengoku is a beautiful world, and the experience of founding and growing a village in this ancient era is pretty darn cool.

162803720.review:
There are some gameplay differences from Medieval Dynasty, one of my favorite games and the only survival game I actually enjoy, but overall the experience can be summed up as Medieval Dynasty set in Japan with some new features. The artwork and setting are fantastic, the addition of shrines with time-limited bonuses make things more interesting, and the change in theme deserves commendation. 

That being said, there are some bugs and stutters and long loading times. Starting the game in particular requires a surprisingly long loading sequence, and even with the video settings turned down as far as I can on a last-generation gaming laptop I still have stutters and temporary game freezes. I am, however, finding the story more compelling than Medieval Dynasty, with your character and your character's childhood friend being refugees who have to try and survive in a hostile new land that recently underwent a serf rebellion. There are different buildings required to make a self-sufficient village, and refugees are scattered throughout the land to be acquired for your settlement. 

Overall, if you like the idea of playing Medieval Dynasty but in Feudal Japan then this is the game for you. Some things don't translate directly, such as the project structures, and there are changes to the types of facilities available, but it is clear the developers wanted to expand upon what was available in their last game while simultaneously providing a time-period experience in a new setting. While I won't recommend this game to everyone, solely because the survival/simulator genre is not for everyone, I do highly recommend this to people interested in village-starting simulators based in feudal Japan. The Total War game was great for simulated feudal warfare, while this game is even better at letting the player create a town from nothing in the same setting. 

TL:DR;
4/5 stars. Setting is amazing. Graphics fantastic but demanding. Long load times to start, occasional stuttering with last-gen gaming laptop. If you want a village-building simulator set in feudal Japan, this is IT. If you think your experience with Medieval Dynasty will directly translate to this game, prepare to be blindsided. I highly recommend to survival simulator enthusiasts, particularly those with an interest in the setting.

Graphics - Not sure if I'm doing something odd with the settings or if it's by design, but they are a bit weird and blurry. The FPS sometimes drops whilst running, and my PC is fairly good. I am however sometimes a bit of an old man with computer things so watch videos rather than take my word for it. The scenery is definitely pretty either way.

Gameplay - Solid concepts with a good combination of building, exploring, and village management. Realistically you can choose what you want to really do as well to some extent. This is personal preference, but I felt like cutting down trees at the start is way too easy - I want to have to genuinely work to be able to build a house or it feels like it cheapens it. I'd like to see it start hard and have perks to make it easier later. The combat is fast and simple, and a lot of it relies on you knowing where a bandit is before they murder you. But I like that people can die in a couple of hits, you or them, as it adds to the realism. Although I'm surprised that a bandit with a spear sticking out of his face wouldn't look a little harder for the guy who threw it. Overall, I very much like what the devs have gone for here and look forward to seeing them build on it.

Bugs - Surprisingly for an early access game I only found a couple of very minor ones relating to an axe not hitting things until I re-equipped it and a false quest marker on the map solved by turning it on and off again. This game is fully playable as is, and I almost wasn't expecting that.

Also, I saw another review where someone was complaining about having stamina exist. I personally like it, but in the custom difficulty menu you have the option to remove it. So that's definitely not an issue. Quest locations are somewhat. I'd suggest the game add a couple more fast travel locations, as if you choose to build your first village somewhere else than your starting area, you'll have a lot more running than you want to do.

Overall I like the direction the game is going. It definitely needs more content especially when it comes to perk trees which are incredibly boring and minimal right now. I'd also really like to see the ability to design your own houses, as you can make stunning villages with standard structures, but I think a building editor would add a fantastic design improvement. I really hope the devs keep at this and allow for modding later.

161411398.review:
I've played for nine hours and really want to be able to recommend this game but it is absolute garbage in its current state. Toplitz is making bank off of the 'Dynasty' title when Medieval Dynasty is the only good game in the franchise. 

The performance is awful and you can read the horror stories in other reviews but honestly there really isn't anything promising about the game at all aside from the general concept of a Sengoku period 'Dynasty' title ON PAPER. The dialogue is so amateurish that it's immersion breaking at times reading text that almost sounds like modern day teenagers talking. There are a handful of good musical tracks but the animations are the worst and the "water-color" style just come off as cheap. The music is also inconsistent and doesn't align with the weird cut-scenes. The model work and textures seem fine but there's nothing that really makes the game stand out at the moment. The character animations are terrible and sluggish most of the time and the amount of heads disappearing from characters randomly is comical. 

You have the option to play in either Third-Person or FPS but they haven't seemed to figure out how to make that work with the movement, building and combat. In FPS your character will frequently engage in a strange climbing animation that will cause your head to detach from your body and spin around so that you watch your torso and limbs "climb" up rocks and obstacles behind you though it makes zero sense because you can't "climb" over anything more than maybe 2 ft tall. In Third Person mode you have the issue of not being able to target properly. For some reason switching between modes seems to affect hitboxes for items and enemies. It's a strange problem that I don't even know how to better describe. It's most noticeable when it comes to building placement which is one of the biggest problems I have with the game.

The building placement is absolutely the worst aspect of the game after performance. The restrictions on where you can build and what can and can't obstruct placement is arbitrary at best. You can have a giant completely vacant lot with no foliage or objects in sight but for some reason you can only place a tiny building at a specific angle. This is SOMEHOW affected by your camera view as well! Sometimes you can't even place a building unless you switch to Third Person and vice versa. To top all that off sometimes when you initially place the building it will rotate it 90 degrees and now you have a door facing the wall of another building and the only way to fix it is to start over again which can take a LOT of time when trying to line things up in this HORRENDOUS system. There is no reason why there can't be some sort of means by which to align buildings in this game. Either that or they need to be FAR more forgiving with clipping. This especially rings true considering how difficult it is to even place an item. Half the time the 'placeholder' that you set down when you decide to build something doesn't even visually match what it turns into when you construct it leading to stairs and doors being in unwanted places. Did I mention you don't get your resources back once you've placed the flooring down which has to be completed BEFORE the game reveals to you that your building has been rotated? It also wastes hammer durability building and re-building. It wouldn't be that big of an issue if you could freely move doors and windows which you sometimes can and sometimes can't!

With all that out of the way I think the biggest problem with the game to me personally is that it doesn't feel Japanese at all. The icon for the game is just fake Kanji and it really symbolizes the crux of the issues with the aesthetics: this is a game that is trying to LOOK like it takes place in Sengoku era Japan. What the game is desperately missing and I suspect won't ever be fixed is that the game doesn't FEEL like it takes place in Japan at all. It feels like a cheap asset pack using the Medieval Dynasty engine with some lite nods to Japanese culture thrown in to pander to a western audience. It's so off-putting at times that I can't help but wonder who exactly involved in the development of this game is the one in charge of adapting Japanese culture because I find it hard to believe it's anyone with anything more than a superficial knowledge of Japan and access to Wikipedia.

It will take a LOT of work to fix the problems with this game. I know Toplitz games are notorious for poor optimization because I was barely able to run Medieval Dynasty when it launched but I'm fairly sure the gameplay mechanics can be fixed at least when it comes to building placement since it's a pivotal part of the game. The one thing that I will remain skeptical of until I see otherwise is the general vibe and aesthetic of the game. 

The most recent Kintsugi Update released with a trailer that is almost comically unaware of itself. Kintsugi is the art of repairing broken pottery with golden lacquer yet you have to carry 5 axes on you at all times because they're constantly breaking and you have to build new ones rather than repair the one you have. An update based on the theme of repairing broken items in a game that won't let you repair broken items. They also state that they chose the Sengoku setting because it was a time in Japanese history when anyone could become a daimyo. This is an absolutely ridiculous justification for placing a game in this era and is clearly just using the words Sengoku and daimyo because of their popularity in Japanese media and subsequent export to other countries. They make it sound like it was a period of upward mobility and social advancement when in reality it was a consolidation of power between multiple warring factions that bathed the land in blood. This game could take place at any point in feudal Japan with the premise of just being a refugee of war starting a village in the middle of nowhere yet they went with a false pretense. The decision-making at Toplitz is baffling.

My "Rant" about the "Control Scheme" situation. 
 This game is unplayable, for me. Honestly, I lasted maybe an hour before the controller controls became too much. Also, st least 1/3 of that time in the game was only because I REALLY wanted to play that world. Another 1/3 was spent in menus trying to look up the control for a specific action, and/or just in the pause menu trying to ponder their choices in control bindings as I cursed the game. I enjoy Medieval Dynasty, and the world of Sengoku looked to be a good play. However, I just can't do it in the present control state for controller. 
   The controls just make NO SENSE, to me. I play Medieval Dynasty and the controls are, in general, logical, and you can re-nap as necessary. It's almost as if they had 2 hats, one with control buttons written on papers, and one with what the control does in-game written on papers, and they just had someone draw one from each hat, then put them together, to decide how they would bind your controls for you. It makes little sense, and not only that, but it makes NO SENSE to not simply lay out the controls in a recognizable fashion from the Medieval Dynasty game. Right now, the controls in Sengoku seem fuddled, confused, non user-friendly, counter intuitive, jumbled, and a complete Mess. Even when in comparison with the typical "Left-Stick Click for sprint" choice that is general for most games, this game says..."Nah, let's make it as confusing as possible, and make left-stick click bring up your radial menu, which was sprint in Medieval Dynasty, and sprint in most games, in general." It's almost as if they actually went out of their way to make the controls as confusing, and annoying, as possible. 
    Go to sprint - open your radial menu to choose tool or weapon. Go to open radial menu - change camera view. Press "Y" on the controller in Sengoku it brings up the crafting menu, in Medieval Dynasty it sheathes/draws your tool or weapon. I equate their controls to the real world, but whenever you want to take a step with your left foot, you have to tell your brain to move your right arm, otherwise you will do some weird dance then just sit down. You have to re-wire your brain to illogical actions, and ones not even in line with the previous game in any way, much less the general and typical bindings of sprint, and other such bindings. 
    It's like going from a racing game, to a flight simulator, sure, some of the buttons will be used on both, but for different things, in different ways causing a giant collection of actions you didn't intend, eventually either crashing your plane into a mountain, or driving your car into the nearest tree. These aren't really "different" genres of games though...they are basically the same games, with almost the same mechanics, same objectives, just different maps/worlds. It makes NO SENSE to have the layout as they did. It's NOT just that the buttons are illogically completely different than Medieval Dynasty, but they are often completely illogically different than the general usage, overall. 
      Oh, and the Right Trigger...ya, don't expect to attack anything, not sure why, but the right bumper is the "attack" button. The left trigger still "aims," but instead of then "firing" with the right trigger (another GENERAL choice in games, and even their other game "Medieval Dynasty"), you are supposed to use the right button. Seriously? As a matter of fact, the right trigger now has NO USE whatsoever in-game, except for changing menu tabs. It is not even shown as bound to ANYTHING for actual play while running around the game world, as I saw in the settings. 
     Maybe it's just me, but to go out of your way to not only ignore and defy the logical and "general" options of most games' typical controls (Sprint, Fire/Attack, etc.), but to also ignore and defy one of your OWN game's general and typical controls, just seems stupid, and makes a game that could otherwise be very enjoyable, a complete mess of jumbled, counter-intuitive, and illogical controls, which leads to undesired actions and consequences in-game. It's almost as if they just became in a hurry, and someone said..."Who cares...just bind crap to do stuff, so we can sell it." 
      Maybe if you've never picked up and played with a controller, and never played Medieval Dynasty, or many other games offering general default logical sprint and attack bindings (left-stick click = sprint, right trigger = attack/shoot, etc.) this wouldn't be an issue. However if you've ever used a controller, you know the typical sprint, crouch, etc., in general, and when it is not only changed to something else, but seemingly illogically bound to something...you become not only incapable of efficient play, but you end up trying to bring up the radial menu by the animal you want to chase down, instead of sprinting at it, THEN watching it run off as you think: "What was the sprint button in Sengoku again? WHY is it left bumper instead of left-stick click?! WHY is it forced bound to left bumper instead of left-stick click?!..and WHY didn't I attack/shoot when I squeezed the Right Trigger?!!!!! FFS!"

[u]Story[/u]

The building mechanics are way too un-userfriendly considering it's almost the entire focus of the game.
It's extremely picky about where you can place anything and it won't give you any further information for why you can't build in that spot. You'll spend an hour just trying to clear out a tiny area to build one small shack, only to eventually find out you placed it backwards. And then there's this issue where it leaves some buildings unfinished until you add a door or something, but then it doesn't list the doors in any of the menus that should have them. [u]User Interface[/u]

149803990.review:
I don't usually do this, but the hate is getting ridiculous: This is an early access game! Early access is not the same as AAA beta access where you see the game at it's dress rehearsal shortly before the game goes live. The vast majority of early access games will not be polished with full content within a few months - realistically more like a few years. 

Most reviewers compare Sengoku Dynasty to Medieval Dynasty, some even call it a clone. I played Medieval Dynasty 5 times over the years and each was to some extent a different game. The first version of early access was actually a lot like Sengoku in the sense that (some of) the main story line was in place and the feel of the game was very RP/management. Over the years more content was of course added, but also the mechanics were altered. The result was rather game changing. As far as gameplay goes, Medieval Dynasty went from being heavy on lore and immersion to being (close to) hack n slash, and then back to a more balanced middle ground. Some I liked, some I didn't, but It's a work in progress and that's the deal with early access. 

Now we got Sengoku. It is not a clone of Medieval Dynasty in the sense that it's the exact same game just in a different setting and I for one am happy with that. Obviously it has a ton of mechanics in common with Medieval, but it is also it's own thing and I'm thoroughly enjoying it. It is of course quite limited still: 

- there are only a few perks which are filled out easily before you're even getting properly settled
- very limited hostility from your surroundings (I suspect more hostile animals to be added later)
- while farming is now implemented, not everything that can be grown is up front available, but enough to be useful
- some materials do not seem to be available yet
- a lot of conversations need updating (example: after 3 years you're still asking certain villagers where you are)

That said, if you play the game expecting a work in progress, you can be highly entertained. I know I am. It is beautiful, most of my village can actually be built even though I'm not very far in the story yet and enough of the story is in place to give at least a sense of where the game is going. Once I hit the wall, I expect to put the game away and forget about it for a few years, and then replay it as a whole new game (literally). Talk about replay-ability! ;)

Very much in the same lines as Medieval Dynasty, but earlier in development and with a more invested story line. Will use this review to compare the 2 but the game itself is well worth the price and a bargain at any discount if you enjoy colony sims/survival exploration.

Pro's over Medieval:
-Large work sites offer the ability to build bridges and other unique structures
-Large map offers far more freedom of build locations
-Fast travel to owned towns makes getting around easy
-More items and a more invested build network between storage's makes for a slower but funner experience
-COOP mode to allow you to play with friends (coming soon to Medieval)

Con's over Medieval:
-Not much farming implemented other then using foraging huts to gather the herbs/grass
-No animals to buy and use as prison wardens for your inmates- i mean, villagers
-Very limited skill tree, levelling up beyond dynasty level 5 is only for the building unlocks at set levels
-Building solely reliant on dynasty level, making the mid-game just building special structures as there are no more quests

TL;DR: Is probably going to be the best relaxed 3rd/1st person colony sim, depending on how well it shapes up over Medieval. Really fun to sink hours into and has COOP unlike many of these types of games.

145641412.review:
After long consideration, I've decided to pen a positive review for "Sengoku Dynasty", a game that undeniably has its fair share of issues. Yet, despite its imperfections, there's something strangely compelling about this game.

TLDR: Pure early access experience. Skip if you prefer finished products (or, atleast, developed further than 0.1.x. version) over works-in-progress. Good style and shows promise though.

Cons:

User Interface: The game's UI, including its barely readable map and lack of clear information on construction durations and etc, feels rather crude and basic. This often makes navigation and planning a challenge.

Combat Mechanics: The battle system is bonkers. Both spear and sword hitboxes feel messy, making combat encounters more a game of chance than skill.

Villager AI and Placement: A sore point for many players. Villagers can be found idling endlessly where they were recruited or aimlessly wandering around. Some NPCs also seem to permanently occupy your village without offering any real interaction or benefits.

Progression Issues: The game's recipies system feels odd. Some fundamental recipes and tools are locked away until higher levels, which can hamper the early-game experience.

Long Progression: Leveling your dynasty, especially in solo gameplay, is a grind. Projects like watchtowers and bridges consume time, resources, and endless running back and forth.

Resource System: The distribution and consumption of resources (by the villagers) feel random at times. Having different storage types and moving materials to your inventory for nearby builds feels overly unnecessarily tedious in this game. 

Running Simulator: The lack of fast travel, combined with the challenge of navigating certain areas, often reduces the game to a running simulator. While some workarounds exist, they aren't intuitive.

Technical Issues: The game suffers from some wonky physics, clipping issues, and long loading times. These aspects, unfortunately, pull the player out of immersion frequently.

Despite its laundry list of issues, there's a reason I'm leaning towards a positive review. The world of "Sengoku Dynasty" offers an atmospheric and deeply engrossing setting. The game's lore, the intricacies of the dynasty system, and the sheer unpredictability that comes from its flawed mechanics create an experience that's oddly captivating. Honestly, I am willing to blame publisher for the most issues, because game sure needs a lot of work but has a lot of potential in terms of immersion, mechanics, style.
