Some of the lost smaller niceties include crafting many items; before you could use the keyboard alone to craft all, now you have to use the mouse to select a quantity. You can't hold E to pick up multiple items in a row (like grass), you have to press-hold E for every item. The in-game menus use bright parchment paper so it's hard to read some texts, especially when it's white text over parchment paper. Building buildings don't use clear-blue areas like in Medieval Dynasty, so it's hard to see through, and the extra walls that you could build were confusing at first; you still have to 'build' the walls that don't exist. Looking at food in the item menu, I couldn't really tell how much food it recovers, or what numbers my hp or food were at. If a tutorial comes up while you're hammering or anything, the player keeps going behind the tutorial.

I do like what the story is potentially becoming over Medieval Dynasty's jokey story, and the setting and visuals are appealing, maybe a bit too bright at times. Not sure about going straight into building a village and dynasty and managing people, I'd prefer having an existing village to visit first like in Medieval Dynasty, and having a chance to do some quests to get a feel for the game before getting to the dynasty. Multiplayer is a nice addition, something I wanted while I was playing Medieval Dynasty, and I wanted to try out this game's multiplayer as well, but like my review, I wouldn't recommend this game in it's current state, and wouldn't recommend it to my friends now to try out the multiplayer. 144611256.review:
Current Playtime: 35 Hours, Single Player.

I picked up this title as I have always enjoyed the Sengoku setting, the style of the game looked great and I enjoy Survival/Colony Management games.

Being an Early Access title, I understand the game is in a bare bones state to showcase the games premise and base mechanics with bugfixes and updates being planned in their roadmap so you should also keep this in mind should you decide to pick the game up early.

On a side note, I really appreciate the Scrolls edition, the level of detail, historical facts and also the preview in the games development has been really fun to read through so far, I have not seen a book-like style for this before and it was really refreshing to just sit back and read through everything alongside the nice visuals and art.

Starting out:
The game obviously has a bit of a slow start being a survival game, I found getting used to the basic controls really easy and quite intuitive for getting around the starting area, finding basic resources and also getting resources like wood to be a simple task but time consuming with basic stone tools.

The starting area has an abundance of raw materials and food to collect making early survival quite easy, I found myself in an enjoyable loop of exploring around the area as I collect materials accompanied by the beautiful soundtrack and great scenery.

Once I started my Village I had to spend a little while getting my log reserves up, this is much easier to do once you have Villagers with tools collecting Logs during the seasons production stages, even more so after you begin trading with other villages for better tools (with just two loggers I can fill my wood storage consistently with a mix of steel and iron tools so no need to gather them myself).

Once your villagers start getting the wood for you, you get to focus on getting food, stone and sticks for a while and begin planning your village layout, I found within about 6 hours I could have a decent village size planned out and created, continuing to expand as I get more villagers to gather more materials for me.

The quests have a good story behind them but I find the dialogue isn't always holding my attention, with voice actors though I believe I will be fully immersed in the story without issues here.

Village management is pretty easy early on and I found no issues getting everything needed to satisfy my villagers consistently, but as it grows I can see it will require some more work to keep everything in check as the demands grow larger.

I have just started my second village in a middle area to allow me an easy travelling point between the two other main villages and the main shrine, allowing me a good trading network and place to find and complete larger special projects, I do hope we get some kind of cart system to help with transporting materials for these but I also know I could use the new village method to get dynasty storage closer for them, I just prefer to do things normally.

I find the skill system is quite good at this stage but excitedly await new skills to spend my spare points on.

Exploring the map I have find a nice amount of hidden structures, caves, traders etc. which has been great to keep me occupied as I travel between villages for trading and special projects.

Combat is obviously quite lacking at this point of Early Access and Boars are surprisingly powerful if you aren't careful, but looking at the roadmap the devs are planning an overhaul of this and I am eager to see how this changes over time, I do hope to see larger groups of enemies in some places rather than only seeing a lone bandit every time, possibly some enemy camps?

either way, this game has been a really fun and relaxing experience even at this EA stage of developement.

If you don't mind taking part in EA games, I can recommend it, if you prefer to wait, in a year or so I'd expect it to release and it will be worth picking up, for those who get it early devs do take on feedback, bug reports and suggestions and the community is very active with these on the Discord.

144570946.review:
TL;DR: It's Medieval Dynasty in Asian setting with more focus on convenience and less on annoying hyper-realism. It's relaxing, fun to play, a bit repetitive but never boring. Patches come regularly and there are no crashes or game-breaking bugs so far. 8/10 if you like slow-paced resource gathering, building managment and a few casual elements of survival.


If you already know Medieval Dynasty, you will recognize the basic mechanics very early. It's the same principle, but with a different setting and a few varying details.

In my opinion, Sengfoku focusses a little bit more on convenience than on absolute realism, which in my book makes Sengoku Dynasty a lot more fun to play than Medieval Dynasty, even in this very early form. For example, inventory weight does not influence walking speed so you can carry a lot more without having to walk super slow. There is also no thirst, just hunger. Food also stays edible longer, etc.

The graphics are nice, not great, but good enough to let you appreciate the idyllic nature around you. Only the walking animation seems still  a bit weird, but in my opinion, the game looks pretty decent and most importantly: it doesn't feel empty.

There is no audio in the dialogues with the exception of a few hello and goodbye phrases. The dialogue menu also is a little bit weird and unusual, but you quickly get used to it. There could be more option in what your character actually says. Sometimes you mainly just click through the pre-scripted dialogues the way the writers intended it. But I like the setting and the NPCs all having a little bit of a back story and things to tell about themselves or the japanese culture and religion.

Gameplay in the beginning is mainly chopping wood and gathering stones and building houses, but after 3-4 hours, the management aspect starts and things get a little more interesting. All of it feels very relaxing without a lot of "survival" pressure or a lot of fights.

At the moment, the menus are still a bit counter-intuitive, description texts are cut off without a way to read the redacted part, but you mostly understand what the menus are trying to say with a little bit of fiddling around.

the game doesn't really explain well how the whole storage system works and which buildings exactly are required for which other building to function, but apart from that, things are pretty intuitive: You build buildings, invite refugees to live in your village, assign jobs and have them gather food and resources. In the meantime, you also complete quests to increase your technology level. 

Very enjoyable gameplay and already very playable despite the Early Access. The devs work hard to deliver many small patches and already improved a lot since day 1.

Original Review:
I.. honestly don't know how to review this one. I both enjoy and don't enjoy this game. From reading some of the other reviews, I don't think I'm alone in this feeling. I want to like it, love it even.. but there are several quality of life things that need to be addressed. If you want to support the devs, buy now. If you want to play an enjoyable game, you should probably wait. Also, for the people looking to see how this compares to Medieval Dynasty.. I feel they're almost nothing alike. Kind of the same idea in that you build up and manage a village and that you'll need to build up your reputation to expand and grow.. but the comparison really stops there.

The game looks nice. The concept is enjoyable. The architecture is lovely. I do enjoy playing the game when I'm not feeling bogged down by all the little things that distract and detract from the experience. The key issues being:

The inventory/tool management/hotbar is a big sticking point for me. I shouldn't have to access the inventory UI anywhere near as often as I do. Making the hotbar viewable from the main screen would be a big help (and I honestly don't understand why it isn't). There are also a lot of inconsistencies around the inventory in general. For example, you can drag tools and items to the hotbar or "quick slots" but you cannot drag armor/clothing to your equipment slots. You'll need to select the item and hit the 'equip' key. If you have a backup tool in your inventory when your tool breaks, it will automatically replace it in your quick slots. If not, you'll have to make a new one which will not automatically replace the broken one. You'll need to open the inventory, find and drag or equip it to the quick slots again. Including if you throw your spear.. and go pick it back up... you'll have to open the inventory and find it and re-equip it. It's just a lot of tediousness that takes away from the enjoyment of the game. There seems little point in trying to make the main UI clean by hiding the hotbar, if you then have to access all the other UI to actually get anything done.

The game also feels rather lifeless. The dialog ends up looking like a text wall where you sometimes can't even differentiate between who is saying what. The dialog UI feels like it needs work overall. Speaking with NPCs should feel like an important conversation is taking place and not like you're just reading a chatbox. Also, where are all the animals and the life to the forests? The ambient sounds are great but there's little visual to back it up. I think I played for 2 hours before I ever saw an animal. In total I've only seen 4 types of animals and there are no variations. Same rabbit, same fox, boar, deer/elk/thing with antlers. Feels very.. 'game asset' and not so much 'wildlife in this beautiful forest'.

There's no way to pause the game. Even in single player. If you need to step away for a few moments, you'll need to save and exit to the menu or else come back to a starving, if not dead character. But then....

The load time.... WHY?!?! Starting the game up.. horrible load time. Loading a save... horrible load time. Exiting to the menu because you can't pause.. loading. Sengoku Dynasty feels like they made a sanbox survival game, realized it's 5 hours long, and gated everything behind pointless quests and level requirements. 


Now, the game is early access and while it doesn't make it immune to criticism it would be pointless to point out small bugs and things that are already on their roadmap.

But if you look at the store page, what does Sengoku Dynasty promise?
[i]Build and manage villages[/i].

Sure, you can put down buildings, if you've done enough chores to get the permission to do so, but there's barely any reason to. 
90% of the building you can build look the same. You have 3 wood types and they all look the same.
All interesting building in trailer and promo pictures are npc owned, you can't build them, you can't use them, you can't build near them. You get same wooden hut 20 times over.
You can't build roads to them. You can't build near existing ones. You can't remove flowers from under them. 
There's some, very obvious flat open areas for building and then it's npc villages and unbuildable hills, which barely feels like open world.

Managing the village needs can be done in a day and is set for years after that.
There's 3 animals that have worse AI that minecraft has.
It's the era of samurais but there's none in the game, the combat is punching boars with spear, with zero weight behind the hits, and your biggest enemies are actually 2 meter hills, that take 1/3 your hp if you dare jump off one.

Quests are barebones "walk for 20 minutes, kill 2 boars, walk 20 minutes again" level on stuff..

And what's on the roadmap? MORE QUESTS???, perks and farming building... And that's coming in "next months" timescale.
That's just simply not going to fix anything.


Now, anything can be fun co-op, no matter how bad the game is, and if you can run around almost naked, laugh at flying animals and process trees to planks, you can get couple fun sessions out of the game.

But if you're playing this game solo it's a 1/5, and that's how it's going to stay for a WHILE, regardless of updates.

144103562.review:
[h1][b]Sengoku Dynasty[/b][/h1]
[b]Sengoku Dynasty[/b] is an early access life sim set in feudal Japan that has loads of potential to become something much greater than it currently is.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
✅ Authentic setting & worldbuilding
✅ Nice graphics
✅ Survival elements that are easy to learn

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
⛔️ Lack of direction
⛔️ Clunky map & UI
⛔️ Light on content

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
The game is set in Feudal Japan and adapts the setting and feeling of the era wonderfully. It fully allows you to put yourself into the shoes of someone who lived in that time and place. You'll quickly have to start collecting items and build tools & structures to survive, and the game makes it fairly simple with an accessible wheel of options you can quickly open, a welcome change from many survival games that make it all extremely complex at the start. The problem is that sometimes the game doesn't tell you what exactly you should do, giving you simple objectives like "use the hammer to build a tent" without any further objective markers or direction, same with the story related objectives. The animals and hunting systems are still in need of work, along with the confusing map and some of the UI.

[h1][b]Graphics & Sound[/b][/h1]
Visually the game looks great, with some minor improvements that could still be done to improve performance. The music and sound design are also very good and fit with the general vibe of the game, helping you embrace the world much more.

[h1][b]Content[/b][/h1]
The major issue with the game is the lack of content. It clearly has a ton of groundwork already done to make for an amazing game and even have an interesting plot, but at the moment, with all the heavy crafting and building elements and not much else, it feels like another typical survival game like many we have already seen and not an ambitious period life sim like some of the other games in the Dynasty series.

[h1][b]Technical Aspects[/b][/h1]
🔹 This review was completed on a Desktop PC. The specs for this unit are as followed.
🔹 CPU: Intel I5-12600KF
🔹 RAM: 32GB DDR4
🔹 Graphics Card: GigaByte GeForce RTX 3070ti

A few minor stutters when walking through lots of tall grass.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h1]
[b]Sengoku Dynasty[/b] is a highly engaging life sim with loads of groundwork and potential to be an incredible game, but it feels like it could heavily benefit from some more time in the oven.

I will revisit in a year or so.

I'm quite disappointed in what this game is offering, because all i can think whilst i'm playing it, is that i could be playing Medieval Dynasty (MD).

There are a number of points i dislike:

-It feels like they have taken the crafting setup of MD and tweaked it to make it annoying, i think people would really struggle if they had not played MD previously. Having to add in crafting stations after building a structure is frustrating although i can see the late game benefits of this (designing your own layout of a workstation). Maybe adding in a workstation to a workstation could be more late game for the more advanced structures.
-Couldn't work out how to craft a shovel, when you're chopping trees, the stump gives an extra log when you use a shovel, this should be available early game. It feels like a complete chore cutting down trees, maybe it's just me, do trees grow back? Who knows.
-Benefits from workers (including assigning yourself) are not real time, they are seasonal, so assign yourself to gather wood, you then have to make sure you have axes in your -general storage- and room in -your inventory- at the end of season so the resources have somewhere to go, I feel this is a very flawed design. I worked hard to build a wood storage in time for the first season to tick over. So you can read into that a lot of mechanics which aren't made clear.
-UI is poor including the map details, can't pin or scroll, tracking quest buttons don't work you have to click it. I can't work out what my villagers actually need and how they'll be affected, i'm pretty sure the number of almost 2k meals for 3 of us per season is incorrect. Then you get plus or minus happiness predictions for the end of season which I cannot fathom.
-One of the first quests outside of the village received from the hunter, he told me to go South when in fact the target was NNE.
-Villagers wander around doing nothing during the day and night, night also feels far too long.
-You feel entirely rushed at the start of the game, forced into building your village where the game wants you to.
-After traversing the map, it really is small and devoid of life - hostile creatures include singular boars and singular bandits which take 3 hits to kill. 
-The map layout is such that it's clear where the devs want you to build 'your own village'.
-You get a guide when you aim your spear/bow which is annoying, if you aim too high (which wasn't high at all) your character resets their stance so you have to re-aim.
-You cannot hold down E to gather, some early game structures require 300 straw = 600 grass, 1 grass gather gives an average of 2 per... hello RSI.
-Underdeveloped talents/specs. I thought you could choose a 'Way of the...' but you can just put 2-3 points in about 3 of the 4, with stats that seem quite overpowered for the amount of time you play the game, I unlocked everything currently on offer in a few hours.
-Lots of placeholders e.g. when you come across a random camp you can see coin pouches, hammer, cloth wrapped something which are all unlootable.
-I don't think you can 'steal' in the game, not that you can loot most of the containers you find anyway
-Small and medium houses only give enough space for 1 villager

I got to the end of Autumn but between Spring-Summer-Autumn it felt like there was hardly any change at all in availability of resources and presentation of flora and character, it rained a bit more in Autumn that's about it.


I liked:
-The music, made me feel like i was across the ocean from MD
-The theme
-Visuals

:(

144061997.review:
I'm torn on this title, I almost want to give it a negative review but the survival crafting aspect is really great. Its  like actually walking the footsteps as a peasant in medieval Japanese times, barely eking out an existence. You can really feel the amount of love the developer has pumped into this game, from focusing on Shinto to traditional naming conventions, you get the idea this is a passion project of theirs.

Which brings me to the negative part of the game, which is also the main part of it. The town building/management. It's horrible. It took me almost an hour just to build a basic house (which isn't terrible in and of itself, but gives you an idea of how grindy it is). Your villagers require certain amount of food and water to remain happy/loyal. The problem is, is that you can only supply them with food IF you have a food storage building, NOT food storage containers. Same goes for water. And logs. And tools. You need to practically build an entire village before you can even have 1 person in it. Speaking of food, I ran across a cart that had a ton of food in it and dumped it into my food storage building and it still wasn't enough to feed em. I'm talking close to 30 pieces of meat, 75 eggs, 20 gabo shoots, and 5 fish. All cooked. My people still starved. In my travels, I only saw 3 hares, managed to kill 1. It gave me 1 meat. I don't see how it's possible to even play the game with that level of difficulty for food. Same goes for water. Once you build a well, you don't just get water, you also need to build a bucket.....per time that you use it and you don't even start off with one (which there's a hidden one if you're careful when looking for supplies when you wash ashore). And you cant build a new bucket from scratch.... you need a whole building for it. I have a carpenter, but she just won't cut wood (the system is very convoluted) You have to have all the buildings built for it; log cutters, log storage building with storage containers in it, general storage with storage containers in it with axes per wood type. then you have to micromanage who works where, what they're going to cut down (looks like she can only cut down 2 trees), what tools they're going to use, where to drop off the resources.... at this point the town management system is not fun and half the time it doesn't even work. The RPG system is also barebones, I'm hoping its just placeholder till they get something better in its place.

My advice.... most of this stuff should be automated (tell someone to chop down trees and they just do it), the storage BUILDINGS done away with entirely (combine them into the production buildings), lower the grind a tad (I cut down all the trees in a 3km radius so I really don't see how a log cutter npc that's gonna get me 2 trees is ever going to help), make supplying your people's needs easier (as well as making the well easier to use).

The game itself is pretty fun, the world is very engaging, with little details that are strewn about that catch your imagination. Just don't try to build a settlement.

I wish I could make a mixed review, because while I really like this game, I can't recommend it to [b][u]everyone[/u][/b] [i]right now[/i].

If you got into Medieval Dynasty late, or never played Medieval Dynasty, and are expecting an Early Access game that's been through some patch cycles, this game isn't for you just yet. I went ahead and bought this game because I really enjoyed the evolution over time that Medieval Dynasty experienced (and continues to experience) as an early access game, and I trusted that I would enjoy it just as much with Sengoku Dynasty. 

With how much I use Medieval Dynasty as a reference point, I will be shortening it to MD from here-forth for brevity.


[hr][/hr]

[b]Graphics[/b]

This game is gorgeous for first Early Access release. I mean, it's classic Japanese country. You would have to actively try to screw it up. It doesn't really seem to be terribly taxing on my GPU, but my CPU sure is getting a workout. I've noticed there seems to be some bugs with CPU threads getting stuck or over-allocated or something, as my CPU utilization will skyrocket until restarting the game, but these don't happen very often. I imagine both CPU related points will be addressed in optimization passes.

I do wish that the HUD scaling was adjustable, as I think some of the HUD elements are a bit too big and intrusive; particularly the quest objective element and the item descriptions when targeting items in the world. The item descriptions themselves are very welcome when getting started, as they provide a lot of useful information about how to interact with the world, but as I get more experience with the game I imagine I'm going to want to be able to turn them off completely.

The weather effects are BEAUTIFUL. Rain and rain sounds stop when occluded by rocks. Lightning illiuminates the rain around it. The rain pitter patters on the ground look really nice.

[hr][/hr]

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Let me start by saying the map is HUGE. I wish I had exact measurements to back up my claims, but it seems like the map is about twice as big as MD's map, at least.

Most everything here is what you expect coming from MD. The game starts out as pure crafting survival until you start recruiting villagers, and then it becomes part crafting-survival and part civilization-management. Villagers can automate your daily tedium, but they have needs of their own, which you'll have to fulfill yourself until you can get more villagers to automate that for you too. 

A few things have changed from MD though:
[list]
[*]Seasons aren't hard-stuck on a 3 day rotation like they were in MD. If you don't like a season, or did everything you wanted to, you can skip to the next season after 2 days. If you have a lot to do, you can spend as long as 5 days in a season. I like this a lot.
[*]Instead of producing and consuming products in real-time, like in MD, villagers instead consume and produce season by season. I really don't like this change as I don't see any impact from my villagers work until the next season. So far this is really my biggest complaint with the game. I'm hoping this is just temporary for the first Early Access release and that the real-time produce/consume mechanic will come back.
[*]Weight is no longer a restricting factor for inventories, including storage sheds (which was the primary reason for upgrading storage building tech in MD). Now inventory slots are all that matters. I like this change, and I want to see it fleshed out more. Right now there isn't a way to increase the amount of storage slots in a building, only build a new building; but using the new building furniture grid system, there is a whole avenue available to natively upgrade building storage, either with more storage chests or better ones.
[*]Villagers no longer have proficiency levels, instead their efficiency is based on the quality of their tools and (like MD) their happiness. I'm neutral on this. It's removed some of the RPG elements, but at the same time I found it really annoying to run around the MD map looking for a villager that just happened to have slightly above average skill in the profession I needed. Better tools in MD also only felt like a slight improvement (for villagers), in that it just meant they consumed less tools over time and freed up some production in the line. So in one way or another better tools mean better productivity in both games, but its just more apparent in Sengoku.
[*]Villager needs can be adjusted like taxation rate in a Total War game. Right now there's only two levels of "need taxation", but you can allow your villagers to consume more food and drink in order to give them a happiness bonus. Another good mechanic that I'd like to see expanded on, particularly a setting that leaves your villagers disgruntled (rather than angry when they have no food/water), but consume supplies at a reduced rate.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[b]Closing Thoughts[/b]

There were some things I wanted to address briefly before I finished that didn't really merit a whole bullet point (although I guess with small paragraphs in each bullet point they're not really bullet points anymore).

The new building furniture grid is awesome. I really like being able to instantly place things in an organized and measured way; but for the people who want to go full Skyrim-modded-housing, there needs to be a way to disable it when placing clutter items inside houses. There also needs to be a way to re-reference tutorials that have already poppped up. The little drum sound that plays every time I craft an item is really cool, because it blends in as part of the music, but I feel like at some point I'm going to want the ability to turn it off.

The shrines are awesome, and the whole folklore of the game is done really well. The boons given by the shrines are really helpful without being overpowering, and the offering items (so far) are simple enough to not be tedious. I love going and giving offerings to Inari.

Overall there is a lot of love in this game, and the only reason I can't say 100% that you should buy it now is simply the fact that not everyone has the patience to watch an early access game grow from the start. Medieval Dynasty has been on a long road, and this game will be too, but it will be worth it. If you know what you're getting into, and you really really want to be in feudal Japan, then 1000% get this game.

Disclaimer: I have played this game in beta and I saw it grow.

Sengoku Dynasty is not the spiritual [b]successor[/b] for Medieval Dynasty. It's more the [b]younger sibling[/b] of it, some things are very similar, some are radically different.

Gathering, building, etc. is very similar.
Producing and village management is not. 

So if you just expect Medieval Dynasty in Japan, [i]you will be disappointed[/i]. Of course, Sengoku looks up to it's older brother for things that worked fine. But it also wants to do things different.

Village Management: You only have to make decisions end of season. All production happen on season change, not daily like in MD. 
Special Projects: There are locations where you need to put in some effort to build them, that does not help you except your dynasty legend level will grow.

There's also a lot not implemented right now. Your villagers don't improve, some quests are stuck / bugged. This is expected in early access.

Still, I like the game. The music and ambience sounds are already great, weather can change within a season, the visuals are great - but so are the hardware requirements.

It is totally playable. The developers do updates quite quick. I already got a lot of hours of fun out of the game.

If you expect a polished dynasty game: Do not buy this. Let it rest on your wishlist for a few months.
If you want to be part of an early game experience: Go for it.

I do not recommend this game to anyone. Watch a stream, wait for some reviews, then decide if it is something you'd like.
I know [i]I[/i] like the game.

Disclaimer:
Everything written in this review is just my opinion.

It is pretty much, what can be expected from a Day One EA Game. Everything seems rough around the edges and the performance is pretty bad.

The presentation of the baseline story, using a voice over in japanese and animated illustrations that resemble calligraphy, sets the mood right for the start.
The game itself has undubbed interactions, that provide "choices" in the dialouges (they are not really choices, just talking points).
And i think that is, why the mood set by the intro, gets lost on me while actually playing. Immersion in an environment with people in it, relies a big part on the spoken language, and without that (apart from the visuals), the worlds setting is pretty inconsequential.
It doesn't matter much, if i build a japanese little house with a cooking fire and a futon in the middle of nowhere, or if build a small brick house with a stove and a bed in the middle of nowhere.
I think what would have been helpful in making it feel more japanese, would be having it set near a bigger city (i know, that goes a bit against the idea of the premise) or having a landscape, that inhabits more well known landmarks, like the Fuji, even if it is just as a picture in the distance.

Furthermore i find it odd, to set a game that is called SENGOKU Dynasty, on a remote Island or something, far away from all the turmoil, the Sengoku Period of japanese history is literally named after (Sengoku = "fighting throughout the country").
I understand, constant raids on your village would be quite annoying, but maybe set it in another period that isn't far from the period you want to show in the game regarding culture/architecture/etc., and prevent this ambivalent feeling.

There is a lot of potential, but as of now, i can't recommend it, if you're looking for an immersive experience in a japanese setting.
I guess Medieval Dynasty might be just as good in providing this kind of gameplay.


TLDR: 
It has potential, but isn't very immersive. The setting is inconsequential and the name is kinda misleading, because you play in a part of the country, where the Sengoku Period is nothing more than a story people tell each other.
So i can't recommend it as of now, if you're looking for an immersive experience.

As far as release day Early Access it is pretty solid. Already multiple hours of content, no major crash or bugs as far I could could experience in my first 8 hours. Some of the UI and controls take a bit to get used to but it's not game breaking and can easily be fixed.

A couple pros and cons beside the obvious high Unreal Engine 5 requirements and missing or unfinished features.

+ Good looking Sengoku Period Japanese island.
+ It's not an empty procedurally generated open world survival game, there are quests and friendly NPCs.
+ Has four different seasons and you don't need to play 20 hours in real time to see them all.
+ You can modify already built building or move them around without any hassle.

- Stone tools are constantly breaking and buildings take a lot of resources early on when you're alone without villagers to help.
- Villagers are not "active", you will get resources each seasons depending on what job you give them and not in real time or at least daily.
- No free build, ( Like Valheim for example ) you can customise buildings and object in them but their size are fixed.
- Only 4 player coop, considering at some point you can build more villages, a 10 or 20 player count would have been an amazing selling point.

Would I keep playing if it was not in the Sengoku period? I'm not sure honestly but it's not the game's fault and it might change once the game is out of early access with more features and polish.

Solid foundation, needs polish. If it ends up with the same features as Medieval I'm certain it'll be the perfect Sengoku-era RPG for people that want a somewhat grounded survival/city builder hybrid.

However, there are big issues you should be aware of:
-Optimization. The CPU is put under too much load in general, and performance worsens if you idle for too long or if you enter a session right after leaving one. Restart your game every time you want to load a save to ensure good performance.
-Some features you'd consider to be basic are missing. Chief among them is Farming, but the alternatives you have (Fishing, Foraging, Hunting) are enough for now. Very little late-game content.

And smaller nitpicks:
-No voice acting, although it doesn't bother me that much
-Lots of running back-and-forth to complete the main quest line
-Loading times are crazy
-Alt-tabbing from fullscreen is weird sometimes
-Other than the quests, you're given very little direction on what to do. Once a community wiki gets set up this won't be a problem but for now you gotta figure everything out yourself

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

In the ever-expanding realm of early access video games, the latest contender comes in the form of an open-world Japanese masterpiece that has the potential to captivate players seeking a blend of survival, construction, and cooperative gameplay. While still a work in progress, this game manages to impress with its depth and immersive qualities, although a few rough edges need polishing.

Pros:

1. Expansive Open World Japan Setting: The game's open world, set in a beautifully rendered Japanese landscape, is a breathtaking feat. From serene cherry blossom-filled valleys to majestic mountain ranges, the attention to detail in recreating the environment is truly commendable. Exploring this virtual world feels like stepping into a traditional Japanese painting.

2. Aesthetic Appeal: Visuals play a pivotal role in capturing players' attention, and this game does not disappoint. The picturesque scenery, combined with meticulous design of structures, characters, and even small details, contribute to an aesthetically pleasing experience that's hard to ignore.

3. Engaging Survival Mechanics: Survival enthusiasts will find themselves right at home with the game's survival mechanics. Resource gathering, hunting, and crafting are seamlessly integrated, creating a dynamic and immersive survival experience. 4. Building Mechanics: The incorporation of building mechanics into the game adds another layer of creativity and strategic thinking. This early access gem provides a sneak peek into the potential of what could become a landmark title in the survival-adventure genre. With a development team dedicated to further enhancing the game and addressing its imperfections, players can eagerly anticipate a refined and polished final product. For an early access release, this game is surprisingly in-depth.  There is plenty of content to keep players happy while the development team works to implement all aspects of the game that remain to be added.  This isn't a 5 minutes and your done demo, this is a 'dinner's 5 hours late but I just need 5 more minutes" game that will keep you engaged with it's beautiful views, impressive content, and easy to understand game play.  Yes, it's early access so it isn't complete but what's there will wow you.
Edit 12/11/2023  Wow. What a difference a few months make.  I look back on some of these negative reviews and hope they all come back and see how wrong they were.
Is the game complete yet?  Nope.  Far from it.  But updates have been timely and steady.  More importantly, they've all been incredibly impactful to game play.  The game is smoother (but by no means optimized), there's a ton of fixes, balance changes, and actual content added.  The farming system was introduced and, with the exception of a small bug on launch, now works incredibly well.
Superkami has met, exceeded, then blown away my expectations.
Still, Early Access is not for everyone.  Me, I hate early access.  It's one of my blocked tags.  The fact there are things hinted at in an EA but not delivered until the roadmap says so drives me up the wall.  And there's the whole 'will they even bother finishing or is this just a cash-grab-and-split title" that all EA gamers end up asking.
Sengoku Dynasty isn't done.  It bears repeating.  There's a lot there and quite a few "hinted" things that I find annoying.  But, I still find enough enjoyment in just what is already in the game to have kept me occupied for 451 hours.  Yeah, I burned out a bit and had to take a 6-week vacation but still, I'm back at it and the game stuck in my head all during that time.  That's telling for a game that's still half a year or more away from actual release!
If you like survival crafting, give it a try.  Offer up your observations and suggestions and help shape what is already a great game into something truly legendary!
Update: 5/08/2024  Several new updates have radically changed the game for the better.  More control, more population, more buildings, new designs, so many wonderful additions, many of which came about from player input.  It's still not complete (far from it) but the promise of the constant updates, hotfixes, and dev interaction on Discord and Steam keeps this title in my favorites list.
Update for 1.0:
Ho-ly CRAP!
From amazing to UTTERLY FANTASTIC in one update.  So many changes, so many improvements!
Sure, I hate the combat but that's a personal preference.  But the game just got a hot shot of absolute creative genuis.  Regional conflicts and conquest, new buildings, more and varied items, new ways to meet Needs, new areas of the map to explore, exploit, and build on.  New character creation including the long-requested female character.  I just can't say enough positive things about the game.  It still isn't perfect but we've already got one hotfix and one update since 1.0 and it's been less than a week.  There's still a long road ahead for this game's development so if you haven't bought this game yet but have been sitting on the fence, get down off that perch and get the game.  The most common complaint I've seen in the very active discord serves is that the game is "too addicting" and "I can't turn it off yet, I've got so much more to do."

I'd say those are some pretty awesome complaints, wouldn't you?
